questions.text: An underdeveloped larynx, a laryngeal web, structural asymmetry within the vocalfolds, or swelling of the glottal margin near the anterior commissure is most likely to result in
questions.solution:
In each of the conditions specified, a shorter vibrating margin of the vocal folds wouldresult, thereby increasing the frequency of vocal fold vibration.

  • In an underdeveloped larynx, the vocal folds would be smaller than normal for a person of a given age and gender.Consequently, the talker would have a higher than normal pitch.
  • With a laryngeal web, the free vibrating edge of the vocal folds is reduced, creating a higher than normal pitch.
  • With structural asymmetry, during closure of the vocal folds, the vocal process of one arytenoid cartilage may slide over the other in such a manner that the posterior parts of the membranous folds are pressed together. This reduces the length of the vibrating portion of the vocal fold.
  • Swellingnear the anterior commissure can also reduce the vibrating length of the vocal folds and increase the fundamental frequency of vibration.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 49 Disorders of Voice, Speech, and Language page no 1120

choices.text: Patient's evaluation of the voice problem

questions.text: Which of the following issues is usually notincludedin the non-medical rehabilitation of persons with voice disorders?
questions.solution:
Non-medical rehabilitativemeasures may be necessary to help compensate for altered anatomic and physiologic conditions, and re-educative procedures are usually indicated in the treatment of habitual or functional disorders. This includes-

  • Evaluation of conditions affecting the patient's general health and the function of the larynx
  • Environmental factors including occupational exposure
  • Psychological adjustment
  • Voice therapy

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 49 Disorders of Voice, Speech, and Language page no 1126

questions.text: Patients who have Reinke's edema or have undergonehormonal virilization therapy or have voices with a lot of'vocal fry,' or have tremulousness in the voice will mostlikely have
questions.solution:
• Patients with Reinke's edema and those who have undergonevirilization treatments experience an increase in the size(thickness) of the vocal folds. The increased thickness resultsin a lower than normal pitch level during phonation.
  • Patients who use vocal fry are usually producing vocal sounds with afundamental frequency below 75 Hz.
  • Tremulousness is oftenassociated with a lack of vibratory control of the thickenedvocal folds and, hence, low pitch

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 49 Disorders of Voice, Speech, and Language page no 1121

choices.text: Has increased for males and decreased for females.
Has increased faster for females than for males.

questions.text: During the past 25 years, the incidence of laryngeal cancer
questions.solution:
The female-to-male ratio has increased progressively in the last 25 years, evenin the presence of a constant proportion of cases in the generalpopulation.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 49 Disorders of Voice, Speech, and Language page no 1130

questions.text: Many different solutions have been applied to the task ofrestoring speech communication following laryngectomy. Which of the following approaches requires the use of thepatient's hands to be effective?
questions.solution:
The battery-powered artificial larynx requires the patient toactivate a handheld artificial larynx that vibrates a diaphragmthat is held against the neck or pharynx.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 49 Disorders of Voice, Speech, and Language page no 1132

questions.text: Functional articulation errors usually do not include
questions.solution:
Dysfluencies are usually associated with stuttering, ratherthan with functional articulation problems. All of the remaining options are types of articulation disorders.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 49 Disorders of Voice, Speech, and Language page no 1137

choices.text: Decide which problem to treat first.
Rule out functional components of the speech disorder.
Determine whether evaluation and treatment of thefamily as well as the patient arenecessary.

questions.text: When multiple dysmorphisms appear in the same patient, consultation with a medical geneticist is prudent to
questions.solution:
With multiple dysmorphisms, genetic predispositions maynecessitate family birth counseling as well as other treatmentconsiderations.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 49 Disorders of Voice, Speech, and Language page no 1139

questions.text: The primary difference between dysarthria and apraxia ofspeech motor control is that apraxia is characterized by
questions.solution:
Impairment of speech movement programming is characteristicof apraxia. All of the other options are appropriate descriptorsof motor speech dysarthria.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 49 Disorders of Voice, Speech, and Language page no 1140

choices.text: Subject the child to direct speech therapy for the disorderas soon as possible.
Focus their attention on the child and tell the child to'speak correctly.'
Be attentive, thoughtful, but nonevaluative listeners.
Take the child to a psychologist.

questions.text: Stuttering behaviors during speech production by childrenoften cause parents to become anxious. The parents of ayoung child with incipient stuttering should
questions.solution:
Anything that brings attention to the problem of incipientstuttering usually makes it worse. If the parents can simplyaccept what is a fairly typical behavior in young children, thechild usually will pass through this stage and continue todevelop communication skills in a normal manner.

Only afterthe stuttering behavior has been present for 6 months to ayear, or if the stuttering behaviors reflect more struggle on thepart of the child, should the child be brought to the attentionof a speech-language pathologist who specializes in treatmentof stuttering in children.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 49 Disorders of Voice, Speech, and Language page no 1141

choices.text: Telegraphic speech and impaired writing skills.

questions.text: Language disorders deal with problems of symbolic representationof thought and action. These disorders caninvolve the lexicon, syntax, morphology (word forms),semantics, and pragmatic uses of language. A patientwith Wernicke's aphasia suffers from
questions.solution:
• The patient with Wernicke's aphasia has a rather fluent but jargon-like verbal output, but the primary problem is in comprehension.
  • Deficits in verbal output and comprehension in speech, reading,and writing arecharacteristic of global aphasia.
  • Telegraphicspeech and impaired writing skills represent symptomsof transcortical motor aphasia.
  • Motor speech output problemsare typical of Broca's motor aphasia.
  • A marked deficit inspeech repetition with numerous sound and word errors characterizesfeatures of conduction aphasia.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 49 Disorders of Voice, Speech, and Language page no 1145

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom or sign of airway obstruction?
questions.solution:
• The signs of trauma to the airway include bloody sputum, subcutaneous emphysema, and palpable laryngotracheal fractures.
  • Hoarseness, dyspnea, stridor, and intercostal retraction are symptoms or signs of airway obstruction.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema is a sign of airway damage but is not specific for airway obstruction.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 50 Airway Control and Laryngotracheal Stenosis in Adultspage no 1152

questions.text: The most appropriate positioning maneuver used to improve a tenuous airway in a trauma patient is
questions.solution:
• The jaw thrust is the most appropriate positioning maneuver used to improve a tenuous airway in a trauma patient.
  • A head tilt/chin lift may be successful in improving the airway but risks cervical spinal cord injury in a trauma patient.
  • Cricoid pressure and hyoid pressure are not positioning maneuvers that would improve an airway. Tongue retrusion would lead to airway compromise.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 50 Airway Control and Laryngotracheal Stenosis in Adultspage no 1154

choices.text: A cricothyroidotomy incision should be made along the inferior aspect of the cricoid cartilage.
The cricothyroid membrane should be incised in a vertical fashion.
Cricothyroidotomy is best used for long-term airway management.
Complications of cricothyroidotomy include true vocal cord damage, subcutaneous emphysema, and subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cricothyroidotomy is true?
questions.solution:
• Cricothyroidotomy is best used for acute or short-term airway management.
  • A cricothyroidotomy incision should be made horizontally in the cricothyroid membrane.
  • Complications of the procedure include -
  • True vocal cord damage
  • Subcutaneous emphysema
  • Subglottic stenosis
  • It is a rapid way to establish an airway in upper respiratory obstruction.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 50 Airway Control and Laryngotracheal Stenosis in Adultspage no 1155

choices.text: The surrounding skin should directly abut the tracheal mucosa.
Permanent tracheostomas result in a longer tracheostomy tract than traditional tracheostomy stomas.
Granulation tissue is more likely to form in a permanent tracheostoma than a traditional tracheotomy stoma.
A permanent tracheostoma is more difficult to cannulate than a traditional tracheostomy tract.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the creation of a permanent tracheostoma is true?
questions.solution:
In creating a permanent tracheostoma, the skin should directly abut the tracheal mucosa.

Compared to a traditional tracheostomystoma, a permanent tracheostoma has the advantages of -

  • Decreased granulation tissue
  • Shorter tracheotomy tract
  • Easier to cannulate

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 50 Airway Control and Laryngotracheal Stenosis in Adultspage no 1157

choices.text: Results from making the opening in the trachea too large.
Results from closing a tracheostomy incision too tightly.
Should always be treated with chest tube placement.
Does not pose a significant risk to the patient.

questions.text: Subcutaneous emphysema after a tracheostomy
questions.solution:
• Subcutaneous emphysema after a tracheostomy results from closing the tracheostomy incision too tightly.
  • In this situation, air escaping from the trachea cannot passively egress out of the tracheostomy incision and may be forced into the fascial planes of the neck.
  • Although this complication is usually self-limiting and does not require intervention, it can progress to pneumomediastinum and predispose the patient to mediastinitis if bacterial contamination occurs.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 50 Airway Control and Laryngotracheal Stenosis in Adultspage no 1157

choices.text: The tracheostomy tube should be replaced with a cufflesstracheostomy tube.
The innominate artery should be compressed digitallyagainst the manubrium.
The patient should be taken to the operating room.
The tracheostomy tube should be replaced with alonger endotracheal tube.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning the immediatemanagement of innominate artery rupture is false?
questions.solution:
Management of massive hemorrhage caused by innominate artery rupture -

  • Tracheostomy tube should be removed andimmediately replaced with a longer endotracheal tube tosecure the airway below the area of bleeding.
  • Digital pressureshould be applied to compress the innominate artery againstthe manubrium.
  • The patient should be immediately takento the operating room for thoracotomy and control of thebleeding vessel.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 50 Airway Control and Laryngotracheal Stenosis in Adultspage no 1158

choices.text: Loss of the glottic closure reflexes

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for aspiration?
questions.solution:
• Tracheostomies increase the risk of aspiration bydecreasing the glottic closure reflexes.
  • Hyperinflation of atracheostomy cuff may also cause aspiration by compressingthe esophageal lumen.
  • A soft, solid diet results in a decreasedrisk of aspiration when compared with a liquid diet.
  • Anupright position tends to prevent aspiration.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 50 Airway Control and Laryngotracheal Stenosis in Adultspage no 1158

choices.text: The carbon-dioxide laser should not be used to coagulatevessels under 0.5 mm in diameter.
The carbon-dioxide laser is most often used in afiberoptic delivery system.
The carbon-dioxide laser is able to deliver a small spotsize.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the carbondioxidelaser is true?
questions.solution:
The advantages of the carbon-dioxide laser include-

  • Precision.
  • Capable of delivering a very small spot size.

The disadvantagesof carbon-dioxide laser include-

  • Not good at coagulatingvessels larger than 0.5 mm in diameter.
  • Cannot be easilydelivered with a fiberoptic delivery system. Although its beamis invisible, the focusing lens usually is treated with specialcoatings to allow the helium-neon aiming beam and thecarbon-dioxide beam to be focused coplanar.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 50 Airway Control and Laryngotracheal Stenosis in Adultspage no 1161

choices.text: Resection of the segment with primary anastomosis

questions.text: An area of circumferential tracheal stenosis in a 49-year-oldman measuring 2.5 cm in length and located 2 cm below thecricoid cartilage is best treated by which modality?
questions.solution:
A 2.5 cm segment of tracheal stenosis located 2 cm belowthe cricoid cartilage could be easily excised and anastomosedprimarily.

Endoscopic laser vaporization is not idealfor circumferential lesions or lesions measuring more than1 cm in length. Alaryngotracheoplasty would not be necessaryin this case.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 50 Airway Control and Laryngotracheal Stenosis in Adultspage no 1162

questions.text: Which of the following has not been linked to cricoarytenoidjoint dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Osteoarthritis is not related tocricoarytenoid joint dysfunction.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 50 Airway Control and Laryngotracheal Stenosis in Adultspage no 1165

choices.text: Laryngeal fracture, resulting in hemoptysis and asphyxiation
Striking the laryngeal skeleton against the vertebralcolumn, resulting in a crush injury
Laryngeal edema release by sudden acceleration anddeceleration of soft tissue, inciting the inflammatorycascade
Penetrating injury, resulting in neck crepitance, pneumothorax,and pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms describes the mostcommon biomechanics oflaryngeal trauma?
questions.solution:
Although the other phenomena related to laryngeal traumaare often present, the mechanism of injury is most commonlythe crush effect of compression of the laryngeal frameworkagainst a rigid body posteriorly, namely the vertebral column.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 51 TRAUMA TO THE LARYNX page no 1165

choices.text: Emergency barium swallow is indicated for patients complaining of dysphagia and odynophagia to rule outa tracheoesophageal fistula.
A CT scan should beobtained in all patients with suspected laryngealtrauma.
A lateral soft tissue film and chest radiograph at thebedside should be obtained to evaluate for pneumothorax and viscus penetration.
MRI scan of the larynx shouldbe done to rule out a hematoma.

questions.text: The radiographic evaluation of laryngeal injury plays animportant role in the evaluation and management of laryngeal fracture. Which statement about the radiographic evaluation of laryngeal injury is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A CT scan is the most valuable test in the diagnosis of alaryngeal fracture. Some patients with minimal trauma mayhave laryngeal fracture despite minimal findings on initial evaluation. A CT scan may be obtained when the airway is stabilized, but it should be considered in all patients suspectedto have laryngeal trauma. The other radiologic studies are, ingeneral, not appropriate, at least for the purpose stated.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 51 TRAUMA TO THE LARYNX page no 1172

choices.text: There is a minimally displaced fracture of the thyroid cartilage.
The laryngeal fracture is associated with laryngealedema
There has been arytenoid cartilage avulsion.
There is limited mobility of one vocal fold.

questions.text: Surgical exploration of the larynx is indicated when
questions.solution:
In general, a patient with arytenoid cartilage avulsion will have a laceration of the mucosa requiring exploration.

Conservative management may be appropriate for the othersituations.

  • If a fracture of the thyroid cartilage is minimally displaced, it may not be possible to improve the situation by operative intervention.
  • Edema without fracture displacement or laceration of the laryngeal mucous membrane need not be treated surgically.
  • Limited vocal fold mobility owing to injurybut not severance of the recurrent laryngeal nerve will likely recover without operative intervention.
  • Injury to the cricothyroid muscle per se is not amenable to surgical repair.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 51 TRAUMA TO THE LARYNXpage no 1174

choices.text: The poor blood supply of partially avulsed laryngeal cartilage.
The fragments being difficult to stabilize.
Lacerations in the airway, resulting in infection.

questions.text: The principles of cartilage fracture repair are especially complicated in the larynx owing to
questions.solution:
All of the above contribute to poor outcomes in patients sustaining blunt and penetrating injuries to the larynx.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 51 TRAUMA TO THE LARYNX page no 1178

choices.text: All of the above require stent.

questions.text: All of the following likely require a laryngeal stent except
questions.solution:
All of the above injuries require stenting because theyare unstable fracturesor full immobilization is needed foroptimum soft tissue healing.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 51 TRAUMA TO THE LARYNXpage no 1175

choices.text: Elevation of the head of the bed.

questions.text: Proper workup and management of a patient with vocalfold hematoma and mild supraglottic edema on flexiblelaryngoscopy include all of the following except
questions.solution:
The described injuries are minor and can be managed withconservativemeasures like -

  • Elevation of the head ofthe bed
  • Voice rest
  • Humidification

A CT scan wouldbe helpful in assessing the full extent of the injuries.

Openreduction is not indicated at this time because there are nomucosal lacerations, displaced fractures, or exposed or dislocatedcartilages.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 51 TRAUMA TO THE LARYNXpage no 1174

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency departmentafter striking the anterior part of his neck against a fencepost while riding a motorcycle at 20 miles per hour. He is alert and oriented, with normal and stable vital signs otherthan mild tachypnea. He has severe dysphonia, mild hemoptysis, and subcutaneous crepitus. The best approach for the management of his airway is
questions.solution:
This patient sustained a 'clothesline'-type injury. Althoughhe is currently stable, he may have impending airway obstruction secondary to cricotracheal separation. No attempt should be made to manipulate the laryngeal or subglottic airway.

Thesafest way to manage his airway is with a tracheostomy underlocal anesthesia.

A 'clothesline' type injury may be caused by a clothesline, chain, or tree branch. Injures of this type occur when the anterior part of the neck strikes one of these objects while bicycling, snowmobiling, or riding in all terrain vehicles. Clothesline injuries tend to be more severe because of the high impact of the force and therefore require special attention. In clothesline injuries, the possibility of cricotracheal separation is a special concern.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 51 TRAUMA TO THE LARYNX page no 1178

choices.text: The procedure is performed 7 to 10 days after theinjury to allow the edema to subside.
A stent is used to buttress the fixation.

questions.text: Best results are obtained in open reduction and internal fixation of laryngeal fractures if
questions.solution:
• Closure of all mucosal lacerations is a major tenet of managing laryngeal fractures.
  • Fractures should be reduced within 72 hours of injury.
  • All viable cartilage is preserved.
  • Stents areused only in unstable fractures or if mucosal grafts are used.
  • Either wires or miniplates can be used to fixate fractures.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 51 TRAUMA TO THE LARYNX page no 1176

choices.text: Reconstruction with laryngeal stenting and grafting

questions.text: The problem of late glottic insufficiency after laryngeal trauma may be addressed by all of the following except
questions.solution:
Supraglottic laryngectomy would be an appropriate choice if the problem is laryngeal stenosis and not laryngeal insufficiency.

Procedures to correct glottic insufficiency are of three major types:

  • Augmentation - With Teflon/autologous fat/ collagen injections
  • Medialization thyroplasty
  • Reinnervation

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 51 TRAUMA TO THE LARYNX page no 1178

choices.text: Mucosal edema secondary to venous congestion.
Infection secondary to poor ciliary function.
Irreversible microvascular injury owing to intimalhyperplasia.

questions.text: The major cause of delayed laryngeal chondronecrosis following full-course radiotherapy is
questions.solution:
Although all of the above do occur and contribute to radiation toxicity in the larynx, the major cause of chondronecrosis isischemia from damage to the microvasculature.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 51 TRAUMA TO THE LARYNX page no 1181

choices.text: Patients with laryngopharyngeal reflux frequently experience daytime reflux.
Patients with laryngopharyngeal reflux typically experience upright reflux.
Patients with laryngopharyngeal reflux frequently suffer from heartburn.
Patients with laryngopharyngeal reflux often suffer from globus and chronic cough.

questions.text: Laryngopharyngeal reflux differs from gastroesophageal reflux disease in all of the following ways except
questions.solution:
Laryngopharyngeal reflux differs from gastroesophageal reflux disease in that patients with laryngopharyngeal reflux usually experience daytime, upright reflux. Typical symptomsinclude globus, hoarseness, and chronic cough.

Onlyone-third of patients with laryngopharyngeal reflux admit to having heartburn.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 52 Infectious and Inflammatory Diseases of the Larynx page no 1185

questions.text: The most common laryngeal inflammatory disorder inchildren is
questions.solution:
Viral laryngotracheitis is the most common laryngeal inflammatory disorder of childhood. It is responsible for 15% of respiratory disease seen in pediatric practice.

Usually, this condition is self-limited, occurs in children under the age of 3 years, and has a seasonal peak, with most cases occurringduring the winter.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 52 Infectious and Inflammatory Diseases of the Larynx page no 1194

choices.text: Referral to radiology for a soft tissue lateral radiographof the neck.
Fiberoptic laryngoscopy to confirm the diagnosis.
Consultation with pediatric infectious disease for antimicrobial recommendations.
Supervised transport to the operating room to secure the airway.

questions.text: The initial management for a child with suspected supraglottitisis
questions.solution:
The child with suspected epiglottitis should be taken to the operating room immediately to establish the diagnosis and secure an airway.

The child is transported to the operating room by the parents, an otolaryngologist, and an anesthesiologist.Examination of the epiglottis may precipitate airway obstruction and thus is not recommended.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 52 Infectious and Inflammatory Diseases of the Larynx page no 1195

choices.text: In adults, the infectious agent is less likely Haemophilus and more likely group A streptococcus.
In adults, the clinical course is usually less severe.
In adults who present with drooling, endotracheal intubationis not necessary.
In adults, progression to epiglottic abscess is morecommon.

questions.text: Adult supraglottitis (epiglottitis) differs from pediatric supraglottitis in all of the following ways except
questions.solution:
Although the clinical course of adult supraglottitis (epiglottitis)is usually less severe, persons who present with drooling usually require endotracheal intubation.

The clinical course of adult epiglottitis appears less severe, with less seasonal variation and airway compromise. Although one must never be complacent with management of the airway, conservative airway management in an intensive care setting is often successful, and tracheostomy is rarely required.

Conservative measures include oxygenation, humidification, hydration, corticosteroids, and intravenous antibiotics.

In adults, there appear to be two relatively useful clinical predictors of the need to establish an airway.

  • Patients who present to the emergency department less than 8 hours after the onset of a sore throat.
  • Patients who are drooling at presentation (in preference to swallowing because of severe odynophagia) almost always require airway intervention.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 52 Infectious and Inflammatory Diseases of the Larynx page no 1195

questions.text: Isolated laryngeal candidiasis is usually secondary to
questions.solution:
Isolated laryngeal candidiasis (without the involvement of any other contiguous anatomic structures) usually occurs in patients who use corticosteroid inhalers.

Severe immunosuppression (owing to chemotherapy oracquired immune deficiency syndrome is associated with the development of invasive laryngeal candidiasis, and, as expected in such patients, the infection is often more serious and sometimes can be life threatening owing to bleeding or airway obstruction.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 52 Infectious and Inflammatory Diseases of the Larynx page no 1202

questions.text: Which of the following may result in secondary muscle tension dysphonia?
questions.solution:
Primary muscle tension dysphonia is a generic term for any “functional” voice disorder caused by chronic vocal abuse ormisuse.

Secondary, or compensatory, muscle tension dysphoniais a result of an underlying glottal insufficiency. Theglottal incompetence may be secondary to presbylaryngis, vocal fold paralysis, or vocal fold paresis.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 52 Infectious and Inflammatory Diseases of the Larynx page no 1213

choices.text: When there is concern for underlying laryngealcarcinoma.
When the lesion has progressed to a fibroepithelialpolyp.
When the lesion has been present for more than6 weeks.
When there is concern for airway obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication to remove avocal process granuloma?
questions.solution:
Although surgical removal of a vocal process granuloma is seldom indicated, there are instances when it should be considered:

  • When the clinician is concerned about the possibility of carcinoma
  • When the lesion has matured and taken on the appearance of a fibroepithelial polyp.
  • When the airwayis obstructed.
  • A professional voice user with significant vocal needs may also require removal.

Vocal process granulomas may take 6 months or more to heal on anti reflux therapy. A persistent granuloma at 6 weeks is not an indication for removal.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 52 Infectious and Inflammatory Diseases of the Larynx page no 1214

choices.text: An adhesion of the vocal fold epithelium to the underlying vocal ligament.
Subglottic edema that is a manifestation of laryngopharyngeal reflux.
A type of vocal fold pseudocyst.

questions.text: Pseudosulcus vocalis refers to
questions.solution:
Pseudosulcus vocalis refers to a pattern of subglottic edema that extends from the anterior commissure to the posterior larynx. It appears like a groove or sulcus.

It can easily be differentiated from a true sulcus (sulcus vergeture) that is the adherence of the vocal fold epithelium to the vocal ligament secondary to the absence of the superficial layer of laminapropria. True sulcus is related to scarring of the vocal fold(s)in the phonatory striking zone.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 52 Infectious and Inflammatory Diseases of the Larynx page no 1190

choices.text: Securing the airway with a tracheostomy tube if necessary.
Securing the airway with an endotracheal tube if necessary.
Antimicrobial therapy with penicillin or erythromycin.

questions.text: Treatment for laryngeal diphtheria includes all of the following except
questions.solution:
Endotracheal intubation can dislodge membranous debris andcause airway obstruction in patients with diphtheria involvingthe larynx. It should be avoided.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 52 Infectious and Inflammatory Diseases of the Larynx page no 1196

choices.text: It is one of the most common granulomatous diseasesof the larynx.
It is usually associated with advanced pulmonary disease.
Its prevalence has been rising since the emergence of HIV.
The clinical presentation is often similar to that of aneoplastic process.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about laryngeal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
• Laryngeal tuberculosis is one of the most common granulomatous diseases of the larynx.
  • It is usually not associated with advanced pulmonary disease and therefore may be mistaken for laryngeal carcinoma.
  • Its prevalence has been increasingsince the emergence of HIV.
  • One-quarter of patients with laryngeal tuberculosis present with airway obstruction.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 52 Infectious and Inflammatory Diseases of the Larynx page no 1200

questions.text: Which of the following is the best speech item for evaluating phonationon fiberoptic laryngoscopy?
questions.solution:
High-frequency vowel sounds such as /i/ or 'ee'position the tongue base and epiglottis high and anteriorly, optimizing the view of the larynx during flexible endoscopy.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 53 NEUROGENIC AND FUNCTIONAL DISORDERS OF THE LARYNX page no 1218

questions.text: Which of the following are examples of speech inParkinson's disease?
questions.solution:
• Parkinson's disease is characterized by reduced loudness andbreathy voice quality (hypophonia). The voice often fades intobreathiness in contextual speech.
  • 'Wet hoarseness'is characteristicof amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and results from poor management of secretions owing to flaccidity.
  • Staccato burstsin speech and harsh voice quality may occur in patients with multiple sclerosis owing to spasticity and tremor.
  • Intermittentbreaks in vowels occur in adductor spasmodic dysphonia.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 53 NEUROGENIC AND FUNCTIONAL DISORDERS OF THE LARYNX page no 1220

questions.text: Which procedure is now infrequently used owing to thelate complication of granuloma formation?
questions.solution:
Although initially good or excellent voice results can be achieved with Teflon paste injection for medialization of the vocal fold, local granulomatous inflammatory reactions to Teflon are now well recognized. Surgical management of this complication is difficult and frequently results in impaired voice quality. Owing to this complication, use of Teflon is now usually reserved for treatment of terminally ill patients.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 53 NEUROGENIC AND FUNCTIONAL DISORDERS OF THE LARYNX page no 1229

questions.text: Which of the following is not likely to result in unilateralvocal fold paralysis/paresis?
questions.solution:
Patients with paradoxical vocal fold motion typically have normal vocal fold motionfor speech but have inappropriate adduction of the vocal folds during the inspiratory phase of respiration.

Transient or permanent vocal fold paresis/paralysis has been observed in patients with peripheral neuropathy, abductorspasmodic dysphonia, and Parkinson's disease.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 53 NEUROGENIC AND FUNCTIONAL DISORDERS OF THE LARYNX page no 1223

questions.text: Speech/voice therapy can be helpful in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• Voice therapy can improve speech intelligibility in patients with Parkinson's disease, increasing vocal intensity.
  • Techniques focusing on breathing control and vocal relaxation may be helpful in patients with muscular tension dysphonia and paradoxical vocal fold motion.
  • Laryngeal maneuvering can be beneficial in treatment of the abnormal laryngeal posturing seen in mutational falsetto.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 53 NEUROGENIC AND FUNCTIONAL DISORDERS OF THE LARYNX page no 1224

choices.text: Botulinum toxin injection into the thyroarytenoid muscle.

questions.text: The current treatment of choice for adductor spasmodicdysphonia is
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin injection of the thyroarytenoid muscle is currentlyconsidered the treatment of choice for patients withadductor spasmodic dysphonia (ADSD) owing to its high rateof effectiveness (> 90%), lack of serious or permanent sideeffects, and the fact that it causes no permanent alteration oflaryngeal structures.

Injection of the cricothyroid muscle is generally ineffective in ADSD but may benefit selected patients with abductor spasmodic dysphonia.

For patients with ADSD who do not respond to botulinum toxin or who are unwillingor unable to tolerate repeated injections, recurrent laryngealnerve avulsion or bilateral selective denervation may providelong-term control of symptoms.

Voice therapy alone is usuallynot effective for the management of ADSD but may extend the symptomatic relief obtained from botulinum toxin injections.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 53 NEUROGENIC AND FUNCTIONAL DISORDERS OF THE LARYNX page no 1237

questions.text: The treatment of choice for chronic unilateral vocal fold paralysis without a large posterior glottal gap is
questions.solution:
Type I thyroplasty provides stable yet reversible vocal fold medialization in patients with a unilateral vocal fold paralysis, although a concomitant arytenoid adduction procedure may be necessary in patients with a large posterior glottal gap.

Collagen injection may be useful in selected patients with a small anteriorglottal gap, but variable resorption may occur over time.

Voicetherapy is useful in preventing vocally abusive compensatory behaviors but will not alone provide adequate vocal rehabilitation for many patients.

Although some authors have achieved promisingresults with various recurrent laryngeal nerve anastomosis procedures, these procedures are often technically difficult and require a prolonged period (3 to 6 months) following surgery before beneficial effects are seen.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 53 NEUROGENIC AND FUNCTIONAL DISORDERS OF THE LARYNX page no 1230

questions.text: Which procedure is not indicated for vocal fold paralysis with aspiration?
questions.solution:
Arytenoidectomy would worsen aspiration by causing posterior glottal incompetence.

Medialization thyroplasty and Teflon injection may be helpful in reducing aspiration in patients by reducing or eliminating glottic incompetence during swallowing.

Tracheostomy may not reduce aspiration but facilitates pulmonary toilet and management of copious secretions.

Laryngectomy provides permanent and complete relief in patients with severe, life-threatening aspiration but sacrifices the voice.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 53 NEUROGENIC AND FUNCTIONAL DISORDERS OF THE LARYNX page no 1236

choices.text: Contralateral reduction in pain/temperature sensation of the face

questions.text: Which of the signs/symptoms is not associated with Wallenberg's syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome)?
questions.solution:
Ipsilateral reduction of pain/temperature sensation of the face is seen in Wallenberg's syndrome.

Wallenberg's syndrome results in vocal fold paralysis, ipsilateral reduction of pain/temperature sensation of the face, nausea, vertigo, diplopia, and intractable hiccupping. These findings result from occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 53 NEUROGENIC AND FUNCTIONAL DISORDERS OF THE LARYNX page no 1223

choices.text: Suprahyoid and paralaryngeal muscles often demonstratepalpably increasedphonatory muscle tension.
Response to botulinum toxin injection reliably differentiates this disorder from adductor spasmodic dysphonia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding muscular tension dysphonia is false?
questions.solution:
Both patients with spasmodic dysphonia and muscular tension dysphonia may derive benefit from botulinum toxin injections. Response to this treatment is not a reliable means of differentiating these two conditions.

Characteristics of muscular tension dysphonia include -

  • Increased muscle tension.
  • Inflammatory changes of the laryngeal mucosa (nodules,erthema, edema).
  • Abnormally increased laryngealtension across various types of speech tasks

Laryngeal massage andvoice therapy aimed at reducing laryngeal muscle tension are frequently effective treatment.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 53 NEUROGENIC AND FUNCTIONAL DISORDERS OF THE LARYNX page no 1245
